summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, responding to a government motion. The order requires defense attorney David Markus to comply with Local Criminal Rule 23.1 regarding extrajudicial statements, finding him sufficiently 'associated' with the defense despite not having formally appeared in the district court. The judge clarifies the rule applies broadly to lawyers associated with pending litigation.

events.title: Maxwell's First In-Person Court Appearance
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell made her first in-person court appearance in New York City. David Markus attended and spoke to the press on her behalf afterwards.

events.title: Court Order on Attorney Conduct
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order requiring David Markus to comply with Local Criminal Rule 23.1 regarding extrajudicial statements about the pending Maxwell case.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court found David Markus, though not formally appearing in the district court, is sufficiently 'associated' with Ghislaine Maxwell's defense to be bound by rules limiting extrajudicial statements.
Markus had represented Maxwell on appeals of bail-denial determinations to the Second Circuit, attended a proceeding, and spoken to the press as her attorney.
The order was prompted by an op-ed authored by Markus opining on the merits of the pending case, which the government argued violated court rules.
Judge Nathan clarified that Local Criminal Rule 23.1 applies broadly to lawyers 'associated' with pending litigation, not just those who have formally appeared.
The court put all lawyers associated with the case on notice that their conduct falls under the rule to protect Maxwell's right to a fair trial.
